From Wiktionary, the free dictionary

English

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Borrowed from German Zaun.

Proper noun

[edit]

Zaun (plural Zauns)

  1. A surname from German.

Statistics

[edit]
  • According to the 2010 United States Census, Zaun is the 33280th most common surname in the United States, belonging to 687 individuals. Zaun is most common among White (94.91%) individuals.

Further reading

[edit]
  • Hanks, Patrick, editor (2003), “Zaun”, in Dictionary of American Family Names, volume 3, New York: Oxford University Press, →ISBN.

German

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Middle High German zūn, from Old High German zūn. Cognate e.g. with Dutch tuin, English town, Danish tun.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /tsaʊ̯n/, [t͡saʊ̯n]
  • Audio (Germany (Berlin)):(file)
  • Rhymes: -aʊ̯n
  • Hyphenation: Zaun

Noun

[edit]

Zaun m (strong, genitive Zauns or Zaunes, plural Zäune, diminutive Zäunchen n)

  1. fence

Declension

[edit]
Declension of Zaun [masculine, strong]
singular plural
indef. def. noun def. noun
nominative ein der Zaun die Zäune
genitive eines des Zauns, Zaunes der Zäune
dative einem dem Zaun, Zaune1 den Zäunen
accusative einen den Zaun die Zäune

1Now rare, see notes.

Hyponyms

[edit]
  • Drahtzaun, Gartenzaun, Kaninchendrahtzaun, Maschendrahtzaun, Holzzaun, Metallzaun

Derived terms

[edit]
  • abzäunen, einzäunen, umzäunen, verzäunen
  • Zauneidechse, Zaungast, Zaunkönig, Zaunlatte, Zaunrübe
  • nicht tot überm Zaun hängen wollen

Further reading

[edit]
  • “Zaun” in Digitales Wörterbuch der deutschen Sprache
  • “Zaun” in Uni Leipzig: Wortschatz-Lexikon
  • “Zaun” in Duden online

Hunsrik

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Middle High German zūn, from Old High German zūn.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /t͡saʊ̯n/

Noun

[edit]

Zaun m (plural Zein, diminutive Zaunche)

  1. fence

Further reading

[edit]
  • Boll, Piter Kehoma (2021), “Zaun”, in Dicionário Hunsriqueano Riograndense–Português, 3rd edition (overall work in Portuguese), Ivoti: Riograndenser Hunsrickisch
